In the 1880's the sport of

"Noble American Savage"
and enjoyed a robust and

An Open Board
A recent Hopkins graduate finds his way to a seat on
the Board of Trustees blocked by an archaic by-law
which prohibits any alumnus from becoming a Trustee
until he has been out of Hopkins five years. The Trustees
apparently feel this will guarantee a wise and mature
membership; rather, it seems more like a design to
keep themselves further isolated from those close to
student opinion.
The Board of Trustees has the final, absolute
authority over all University matters. Yet students are
changing at a rapid pace, and the University will,
hopefully, be asked to improve its relationship with
society and its own academic community. The Trustees,
however, with their built-in time lag, are setting the
stage for the acute crisis that inevitably develops when
an institution becomes too rigid to make needed
reforms. They see the Hopkins academic community
through the prism of the alumni magazine, Dr. Gordon's
presentations, and editorials in the Baltimore Sun.
While we don't expect the Board to become a
vanguard of the revolution with the addition of a few
young alumni, their presence could add new
perspectives to the Trustees' narrow views. At the very
least, communication could begin between those who
make policy and those who have to live with it. In fact,
the University would benefit from regular contacts
between Board members, students and faculty. For
example, with the present enfeebled position of
undergraduate education, it is nothing less than absurd
for a Trustee to assert, "We don't need any more
representation of undergraduate viewpoint on the
Board. We already have enough."
Becoming an alumni trustee will not be easy for young
graduates, even if the five-year clause is actually
removed. They also have to be nominated and elected by
an Alumni Association not noted for its innovation. But
for the sake of the University, the Board should
immediately join with a number of other schools
throughout the country and open the way to younger
and more diverse views.

Bold Innovation
Freshman seminars, as every department chairman
will glibly tell you, is a good idea. But, as is often true at
Hopkins, faculty members become too engrossed with
academic innovations and many times forget longrange problems.
A few years ago, the Biology Department began
freshman seminars. Now Computer Sciences, English,
Social Relations,Physics and German are following suit
next fall. Who knows, maybe in a few more years there
will be more freshman seminars and even seminars
open to sophomores, juniors and seniors.
It's simply terrifying to think of all the course choices
each student will have to make every September and
January if this happens. We urge that a faculty-student
committee (with equal representation and open
meetings) be formed to judiciously consider this matter.
Without prior thought, Homewood may become
inundated with classes, ruining the current
undergraduates' idyllic life.

College Aid

Not Much Help
Fred M. Hechinger
American higher education faces two
the
problems:
separate
financial
universities' deficits and the students' (or
their parents') strained budgets. University
deficits, as a result of rising costs and
declining research funds, have become'
critical in the past two years, with no end in
sight. As the deficits increase, colleges must
raise tuition, thereby further threatening
family budgets, already hard-pressed by
inflation and recession.
Last week President Nixon sent to
Congress a program designed to aid the
students. But the package, if Congress
approves it, would do little for the colleges
and might leave them deeper in the red.
Ironically, despite its stress on student aid,
the proposal was greeted with reservations
even on that score.
Fewer Grants'
At the heart of the President's plan is
increased reliance on loans rather than
grants. Many educators consider this
concept sound because it may enhance the
student's appreciation of his education's
value if he had made a personal investment.
For students from the lowest income
families, the largest proportion of the aid
package would be a direct grant of $1,000 a
year, augmented by a $400 loan. Moreover,
for children with,families with incomes of
$10,000 or less, the loan portion is interestFred M. Hechinger is Education Editor for the

free, Federally subsidized, and repayable in
up to 20 years at a low three per cent rate. All
loans are to be made by private money
lenders, not the Government.
Families in income brackets above the
subsidized loan cutoff level would be eligible
for a new form of loans--guaranteed by the
Government but not subsidized. A subsidized
loan carries rates lower than prevailing
rates, with the Government making up the
difference. With a guaranteed loan, the
Government pays none of the interest but
insures repayment of the loan.
Although the Administration has offered
assurances that the guaranteed loans would
be freely available, they would be repayable
at or near the going rate. For long-term
loans, this would result in an increase of the
tuition costs. The Government hopes,
however, that the banks would show their
appreciation for the risk-free nature of the
loans by offering some special discounts.
However, past experience has shown that
banks have little enthusiasm for student
loans during tight-money periods.
Since the new Nixon proposal would lower
eligibility for the subsidized low-interest
loans from the present $15,000 to the $10,000
bracket, a sizable segment of middle-class
families would feel an additional pinch.
And, apart from an institution's own
scholarship subsidies, more students mean
greater deficits. University leaders are
asking for matching grants to the schools

from the catalogue. The catalogue shall also list when courses will be

An Open Board
A recent Hopkins graduate finds his way to a seat on
the Board of Trustees blocked by an archaic by-law
which prohibits any alumnus from becoming a Trustee
until he has been out of Hopkins five years. The Trustees
apparently feel this will guarantee a wise and mature
membership; rather, it seems more like a design to
keep themselves further isolated from those close to
student opinion.
The Board of Trustees has the final, absolute
authority over all University matters. Yet students are
changing at a rapid pace, and the University will,
hopefully, be asked to improve its relationship with
society and its own academic community. The Trustees,
however, with their built-in time lag, are setting the
stage for the acute crisis that inevitably develops when
an institution becomes too rigid to make needed
reforms. They see the Hopkins academic community
through the prism of the alumni magazine, Dr. Gordon's
presentations, and editorials in the Baltimore Sun.
While we don't expect the Board to become a
vanguard of the revolution with the addition of a few
young alumni, their presence could add new
perspectives to the Trustees' narrow views. At the very
least, communication could begin between those who
make policy and those who have to live with it. In fact,
the University would benefit from regular contacts
between Board members, students and faculty. For
example, with the present enfeebled position of
undergraduate education, it is nothing less than absurd
for a Trustee to assert, "We don't need any more
representation of undergraduate viewpoint on the
Board. We already have enough."
Becoming an alumni trustee will not be easy for young
graduates, even if the five-year clause is actually
removed. They also have to be nominated and elected by
an Alumni Association not noted for its innovation. But
for the sake of the University, the Board should
immediately join with a number of other schools
throughout the country and open the way to younger
and more diverse views.

Bold Innovation
Freshman seminars, as every department chairman
will glibly tell you, is a good idea. But, as is often true at
Hopkins, faculty members become too engrossed with
academic innovations and many times forget longrange problems.
A few years ago, the Biology Department began
freshman seminars. Now Computer Sciences, English,
Social Relations,Physics and German are following suit
next fall. Who knows, maybe in a few more years there
will be more freshman seminars and even seminars
open to sophomores, juniors and seniors.
It's simply terrifying to think of all the course choices
each student will have to make every September and
January if this happens. We urge that a faculty-student
committee (with equal representation and open
meetings) be formed to judiciously consider this matter.
Without prior thought, Homewood may become
inundated with classes, ruining the current
undergraduates' idyllic life.

College Aid

Not Much Help
Fred M. Hechinger
American higher education faces two
the
problems:
separate
financial
universities' deficits and the students' (or
their parents') strained budgets. University
deficits, as a result of rising costs and
declining research funds, have become'
critical in the past two years, with no end in
sight. As the deficits increase, colleges must
raise tuition, thereby further threatening
family budgets, already hard-pressed by
inflation and recession.
Last week President Nixon sent to
Congress a program designed to aid the
students. But the package, if Congress
approves it, would do little for the colleges
and might leave them deeper in the red.
Ironically, despite its stress on student aid,
the proposal was greeted with reservations
even on that score.
Fewer Grants'
At the heart of the President's plan is
increased reliance on loans rather than
grants. Many educators consider this
concept sound because it may enhance the
student's appreciation of his education's
value if he had made a personal investment.
For students from the lowest income
families, the largest proportion of the aid
package would be a direct grant of $1,000 a
year, augmented by a $400 loan. Moreover,
for children with,families with incomes of
$10,000 or less, the loan portion is interestFred M. Hechinger is Education Editor for the
New York Times.

free, Federally subsidized, and repayable in
up to 20 years at a low three per cent rate. All
loans are to be made by private money
lenders, not the Government.
Families in income brackets above the
subsidized loan cutoff level would be eligible
for a new form of loans--guaranteed by the
Government but not subsidized. A subsidized
loan carries rates lower than prevailing
rates, with the Government making up the
difference. With a guaranteed loan, the
Government pays none of the interest but
insures repayment of the loan.
Although the Administration has offered
assurances that the guaranteed loans would
be freely available, they would be repayable
at or near the going rate. For long-term
loans, this would result in an increase of the
tuition costs. The Government hopes,
however, that the banks would show their
appreciation for the risk-free nature of the
loans by offering some special discounts.
However, past experience has shown that
banks have little enthusiasm for student
loans during tight-money periods.
Since the new Nixon proposal would lower
eligibility for the subsidized low-interest
loans from the present $15,000 to the $10,000
bracket, a sizable segment of middle-class
families would feel an additional pinch.
And, apart from an institution's own
scholarship subsidies, more students mean
greater deficits. University leaders are
asking for matching grants to the schools
